content.description: Start with the flake, and use the obvious finger crack and crimpy sidepull to go straight up.
content.protection: TR off the oak tree and/or gear.
content.location: This route is located directly left of the oak tree, between Easy Overhang and Crag 1 Slab.

content.description: Go straight up the thin, steep face right of the Short Job dihedral. It is one of the better routes at the crag.
content.location: This is on the face to the right of the Short Job dihedral on the left side of the crag.

content.description:
Climb up the dihedral and through the small roof. 

Boston Rocks 2nd ed. ups the grade from 5.7 to 5.8 and notes that it's gotten harder as holds have broken.
content.location: It is in the dihedral on the left end of the crag, 10-15 feet past the tree growing right along the cliff.

content.description:
Climb up through an A-shaped roof into a corner, and follow an offwidth crack to the top. 

  To be edited in.
content.protection:
A gear anchor may be obtained. Longer slings will help reduce rope friction and wear. 

  To be edited in.
content.location:
This is right of Crag 1 Slab and left of Lotsa Pockets. It starts at an A-shaped roof/alcove. 

  To be edited in.

content.description:
Start on the boulder below the center of the overhang, pull the overhang on jugs, then cruise to the top following the crack. 

  It can also be bouldered, since pulling the lip at the start is the crux and the fun part.
content.location: Start atop the boulder below the overhang.

content.description: A good easy route up one of the tallest near-vertical sections of the crag. Follow the crack up to flakes above, trending right. The first portion is the most interesting part.
content.location: Starts up below a crack near the left end of the large overhang on the right side of the crag.

content.description:
Climb through the crack to the right of the blocky Quick Descent route. Trend right toward the tallest part of the cliff. The upper slab section has thinner moves, but there is no noticeable crux - just easy climbing. Finish at the main/upper ledge and descend through the Descent Chimney. 

  You can also extend the climb by scrambling up the blocky face that sits atop the main ledge. Enjoy the view of Boston!
content.location: It is in the middle of Crag 1 just right of the distinguishable Quick Descent route. This is one of the cliff's longest routes as it tends right to the tallest part of the cliff (to the main/upper ledge).

content.description: Fern is steady 5.3 climbing straight up the finger crack on the steepish, 25-foot face to the right of Offwidth route. The crack alternates between unprotectable, flaring grooves and finger pockets that take gear. Juggy holds make for an easy topout at the middle ledge; you can descend by carefully scrambling down the steep gully to the (climber's) right. You can also continue to scramble from the middle ledge to the top of Pinnacle Rock and walk off the summit trail.
content.protection: Gear up to 2" or toprope with a gear anchor.
content.location: Look for the distinguishable finger crack between the Offwidth route and the descent gully. The route finishes to the right of the double-trunk tree on the middle ledge.

content.description: Follow the flakes up the cliff, just left of the tree.
content.protection: TR off trees and/or gear, or use a pad.
content.location: Start just left of the oak tree growing right by the cliff face.

content.description: Start at the base of Offwidth, and climb up left, using finger pockets to gain the slab (per Boston Rock 2nd Edition).
content.protection: Long webbing or static rope for toprope anchors.

content.description:
Beginner's Class is one of the longer climbs at Crag 1.

 Starting at the rounded "arete" on the large buttress at Crag 1, climb up the small overlap to gain the slab. Follow the path of least resistance up the slabs to the top. Sit start for extra style points.
content.protection: There are trees at the top for an anchor.
content.location: It is in the middle of Crag 1 roughly 6 feet left of "Madcap".

content.description:
This crag is probably the 3rd tallest of these rocks at 25 feet tall and faces north It has some decent climbing.

 L->R: A. OHB, 8. B. Short Job, 7-8, 1p, 25', TR. C. So Fine, 8-9, 1p, 25', TR. D. Easy Overhang, 6-7, 1p, 25', TR. E. Delirium, 9. F. Crag 1 Slab, 6-8, 1p, 25', TR. GF. Alternate start to Crag 1 Slab, 6. H. Offwidth, 7, 1p, TR. I. Black Hole, 2. J. Fern, 3, 1p, 25' (can extend), TR or gear. K. Facelift, 3. L. Quick Descent, 0. M. Lotsa Pockets, 3, 1p, 35', TR or gear. N. Beginner's Class, 4, 1p, 40', TR. O. Madcap, 4-6, 1p, 35', TR. PO. Madcap Direct, 10. Q. Unknown, 12. R. O.H.C., 7-8, 1p, 35', TR. photo S. One More Time, 7. T. The Golden Road (traverse), 10.

 To the right are some boulder problems.

 Per Curtis Tripp: this crag has been noted as Pinnacle Rock on a DCR Middlesex Fells trail map.
